subNodes.conversationText: root
The Minister of Peace was talking to another man near a proud-looking tent. He greeted <FirstName> and introduced <him/her> to Dudow's ambassador to Wan.
[Continue.]
"My name is Astimund. A pleasure to meet you."
[Continue.]

A guttural, choking sound interrupted them. It came from the tent. Looking inside, <FirstName> saw a feeble old man, mouth open wide, fast asleep and snoring loudly. He was propped up on a pile of velvet cushions.

The minister loosened the cords that kept the tent flaps open. <FirstName> could no longer see the old man, but <he/she> still heard his snores.
[Continue.]
"You must want to know why we want to talk to you. The ambassador will tell you some of the details. Then we'll get to business."
"I'm listening."
"We're escorting His Majesty to Wan. There, we'll discuss the fate of Ghund, a strip of land in the mountains between our countries."
[Continue.]
"One of the Warlike Governors took Ghund by force a century ago. It belongs to us, and we hope to convince Wan to give it back."
"Go on."

"As you've seen, His Majesty is old. His daugher Zidae will inherit the throne -- sooner rather than later, we think. Zidae believes that Wan's possession of Ghund is shameful and urgent, a casus belli.

"His Majesty does not share her views. He hopes that going to the Grand Governor's palace will signal how important the friendship between our countries is."
"This land must be very valuable."
"It's a barren scrap. Nothing grows there, and nothing can be mined there."
[Continue.]
"That said," put forward the minister, "it belonged to Dudow for centuries before Wan invaded. There are things that have no price -- honor, pride, the claims an ancient kingdom has to its own soil."
[Continue.]
The ambassador said nothing.
"Why approach Wan about this now?"

"As you've seen, His Majesty is old. His daugher Zidae will inherit the throne -- sooner rather than later, we think. Zidae believes that Wan's possession of Ghund is shameful and urgent, a casus belli.

"His Majesty does not share her views. He hopes that going to the Grand Governor's palace will signal how important the friendship between our countries is."
"What does any of this have to do with me?"
"I told you that <he/she> might not care about the particulars, Astimund."
[Continue.]
"<He/She> should know that what <he/she> tells us could have major consequences."
[Continue.]
The minister motioned for Astimund to continue.
[Continue.]

"As you've seen, His Majesty is old. His daugher Zidae will inherit the throne -- sooner rather than later, we think. Zidae believes that Wan's possession of Ghund is shameful and urgent, a casus belli.

"His Majesty does not share her views. He hopes that going to the Grand Governor's palace will signal how important the friendship between our countries is."
"That sounds like delicate work. Why now?"

"As you've seen, His Majesty is old. His daugher Zidae will inherit the throne -- sooner rather than later, we think. Zidae believes that Wan's possession of Ghund is shameful and urgent, a casus belli.

"His Majesty does not share her views. He hopes that going to the Grand Governor's palace will signal how important the friendship between our countries is."
"No one will remember the king's visit in five years."
"That's where I come in. I hope to formalize talks about the disputed territory."
[Continue.]
"Any friction between our two countries could be disastrous for Dudow -- Wan would swallow us whole if it came to war."
"Would the king's daughter really try to start a war with Wan?"

"I hope not, but there's popular support for reclaiming Ghund. Some people romanticize such disputes. Needless to say, a war between the countries would be a disaster for Dudow -- Wan would swallow us whole."
[Continue.]
"Our generals don't think so, Astimund. Wan isn't what it was fifty or even ten years ago, and Dudow is not its only enemy."
[Continue.]
"Dudow isn't Wan's enemy, Minister. Please remember that this is a diplomatic mission. Remember His Highness's wishes."
[Continue.]
"I do, Astimund. As one of the king's own cabinet, I do remember his wishes. Don't accuse me of forgetting -- and don't you forget your place." The two glared at each other.
[Continue.]
The two glared at each other.
"I'm uninterested in your squabbles. What do you want from me?"
"Apologies," said Astimund to <FirstName>.
[Continue.]
"Yes, let's not keep our young guest wondering. Tell <him/her> why we took the long road to Wan."
[Continue.]
"Normally, we'd avoid these woods. There are safer roads for a king to travel. But the Minister persuaded His Highness to seek out the witches who live here."
[Continue.]
"It's said that witches can see the future!" he said, whispering for some reason. "Isn't that so?"
"Not exactly."

"The old legends say that in times of great uncertainty, brave kings have entered these woods and sought the witches.

"Some stories say the house is in the north, others in the south; some say it's timber, and others that it's made of stone. But all agree that the witches prophecies have changed the fate of the kingdom many times."
"We receive visions, not prophecies."

"The old legends say that in times of great uncertainty, brave kings have entered these woods and sought the witches.

"Some stories say the house is in the north, others in the south; some say it's timber, and others that it's made of stone. But all agree that the witches prophecies have changed the fate of the kingdom many times."
"It's true," <he/she> said, smiling mysteriously.
"See, Astimund!"
[Continue.]
"I see only a stranger whose words may or may not be truthful."
[Continue.]
"Oh, Astimund!"
[Continue.]

"The old legends say that in times of great uncertainty, brave kings have entered these woods and sought the witches.

"Some stories say the house is in the north, others in the south; some say it's timber, and others that it's made of stone. But all agree that the witches prophecies have changed the fate of the kingdom many times."
[Continue.]
"Some people call those old legends fairy tales."
[Continue.]
"His Majesty doesn't."
"No vision tells the whole truth, for there is no whole truth to tell," the witch cautioned.
The minister wasn't interested in the young witch's caveat.
[Continue.]
"Will you tell us what you see?"
"Will you tell us what you see?"
"I will try. I may see nothing."
The two men stared at the witch expectantly, as if hoping to see some glimpse of her vision themselves.
[Continue.]

<FirstName> closed <his/her> eyes. It had been a long time since someone asked <him/her> for a vision, and visions could be fickle. <His/Her> own recent experiences made that plain. Moreover, if the kings of Dudow used to consult Eldest Lady, would a mere minister consulting an as-of-yet covenless witch do the trick?
[Continue.]

But then: A stony crag. A woman kneeling on top of it. She had driven a sword into the chest of a man. She stood, using the sword as a support, but then slipped. Her left hand waved frantically in thin air, but her right still gripped the hilt of the sword. The vision ended before she either fell or recovered her balance.
[Continue.]
<FirstName> related the vision to the ambassador and the minister.
[Continue.]
"Zidae! It must be. What did she look like?"
"We dont really see detail in that way. Our visions are more like ideas."
"If it was Zidae, the vision seems like a warning."
[Continue.]
"A warning? How? Her enemy was dead. She didn't fall when she slipped."
[Continue.]
"You make quick conclusions, Minister. Maybe the slain man was Dudow. And maybe the woman wasn't Princess Zidae at all. Maybe she was the Grand Governor of Wan. She's said to fight with a sword."
[Continue.]
"Nonsense. Can you tell us what it means, witch?"
"I can tell you no more than what the vision showed me."

The ambassador and minister argued for several minutes about the meaning of the vision. Where the ambassador saw doom, the minister saw promise. To the minister, the vision validated his conviction that Dudow had a strong position and ought to be bold with Wan; to the ambassador, the vision suggested that Dudow's position was precarious at best -- assuming anything truthful could be learned from a wandering witch.

Finally, the ambassador suggested waking up the king and letting him decide.
[Continue.]

"You're right. But if he's sleeping deeply we'll let him rest -- he has so much trouble if he doesn't get enough rest."

The Minister of Peace turned to the witch. "Thank you for coming. We've had a vision from a witch and can stop looking for Eldest Lady's house."
[Continue.]
"Yes. Maybe now we can get back on the road."
[Continue.]

"Soon, soon. We'll leave within the week, once His Majesty is fit to travel again... Hmm. It occurs to me -- Young witch, could you return to us tomorrow, in case His Majesty wants to meet you and hear the vision from yours lips himself?"
"Of course."
Satisfied, the ambassador and Minister of Peace said their farewells and went into the king's tent, closing the flaps behind them.
[End.]

actions.a_parameter_1: The young witch had a vision and described it to the Minister of Peace and Astimund. The minister asked the witch to come back the next day in case the king wanted to hear it from the witch's own lips.

subNodes.conversationText: [End.]

actions.a_parameter_1: The young witch had a vision and described it to the Minister of Peace and Astimund. The minister asked the witch to come back the next day in case the king wanted to hear it from the witch's own lips.

subNodes.conversationText: "Maybe -- If I happen to come this way."
Satisfied, the ambassador and Minister of Peace said their farewells and went into the king's tent, closing the flaps behind them.
"We'll see. I don't tell the future, remember?"
Satisfied, the ambassador and Minister of Peace said their farewells and went into the king's tent, closing the flaps behind them.
[Continue.]
"Yes -- we'll be on the road shortly."
[Continue.]
The ambassador and Minister of Peace offered their thanks and farewells and went into the king's tent, closing the flaps behind them.
[End.]

actions.a_parameter_1: The young witch had a vision about the fate of Rigadah and described it to the Minister of Peace and Astimund.

subNodes.conversationText: <FirstName> shook her head.

The ambassador and minister argued for several minutes about the meaning of the vision. Where the ambassador saw doom, the minister saw promise. To the minister, the vision validated his conviction that Dudow had a strong position and ought to be bold with Wan; to the ambassador, the vision suggested that Dudow's position was precarious at best -- assuming anything truthful could be learned from a wandering witch.

Finally, the ambassador suggested waking up the king and letting him decide.
"It's...hard to describe her. I can't give you any details."
"If it was Zidae, the vision seems like a warning."
"I won't do anything to help you unless you give me something in return."
The ambassador raised his hands as if to say that he had nothing to give .
[Continue.]

The minister looked flummoxed for a moment, then pulled a ring off his finger and handed it to <FirstName>.

"That's a very valuable piece, made by one of the best jewelers in the capital," he said. "Now -- what do you see?"
[Continue.]
The two men stared at the witch expectantly, as if hoping to see some glimpse of her vision themselves.
"Dudow is wise to trust the visions of those that see," said <FirstName>.
Astimund looked askance at <FirstName>.
[Continue.]
"Will you tell us what you see?"
<FirstName> waited.
"Apologies," said Astimund to <FirstName>.
"I'm uninterested in your squabbles. What do you want from me?"
<FirstName> waited.
"Go on."
"Any friction between our two countries could be disastrous for Dudow -- Wan would swallow us whole if it came to war."
[Continue.]
"The king looks very frail. Why did you bring him through the woods?"
"Why indeed?" said Astimund, more to the minister than to <FirstName>.
[Continue.]
"We'll explain."
[Continue.]
"We're escorting His Majesty to Wan. There, we'll discuss the fate of Ghund, a strip of land in the mountains between our countries."
"Very well, but my time is short."
"Of course. He'll be as brief as possible."
[Continue.]
"We're escorting His Majesty to Wan. There, we'll discuss the fate of Ghund, a strip of land in the mountains between our countries."
Once again, the minister and ambassador stood outside the king's tent. The flaps were closed. The young witch's approach startled them.
[Continue.]
"Oh -- the witch. What are you doing here?"
[Continue.]
"You asked <him/her> to come by. <He/She> was going to describe <his/her> vision to His Majesty."
[Continue.]
"Right, right. Oh... But -- His Majesty -- His Majesty is dead!"
[Continue.]

"Hamilcar!" hissed the ambassador to the Minister. "Apologies -- Minister. Be discreet! This is very sensitive news, and you've just disclosed it to a wandering witch. The rest of the camp can't know, not yet."
[Continue.]

The Minister of Peace choked on his grief. Astimund grunted, opened the flaps of the king's tent, and forced him in, following behind. He glanced back at the witch. Reluctantly, he gestured for <him/her> to follow. <He/She> did.
[Continue.]
"You must swear, witch -- swear that you won't breathe a word of this to anybody."
[Continue.]
On the pile of cushions lay the body of King Setus II. He looked just as he had before -- feeble, propped up, mouth gaping. But he was no longer snoring.
[Continue.]
"Swear that you won't talk about this."
"Who would I tell?"
"Who wouldn't you tell? I'm sure witches like gossip as much as anyone."
"How did this happen?"
"His Majesty was in bad health. I think he knew this journey would be his last. He never would have left the castle if he didn't believe it was vital to his legacy."
[Continue.]
"We did everything we could," said the Minister of Peace gravely. "Oh, it's horrible, horrible. Curse Wan, curse this mission."
[Continue.]
Astimund shook his head. "No. Don't think that way."
[Continue.]
"Our mission is important. This news could disrupt it. We can't let that happen. We need to treat the situation with delicacy."
"Why are you trying to keep this secret?"
"Our mission is important. This news could disrupt it. We can't let that happen. We need to treat the situation with delicacy."
[Continue.]

"I agree, to a point. We can't let the camp know yet; the announcement must be formal, and we must prepare for the mourning that will follow. But we have to send news to the capital at once. Is the will of the crown now behind this mission? I'm not so sure."
[Continue.]
"Let's not be too hasty. We need to --"
[Continue.]
"I need to inform the royal family and the rest of the cabinet. Dudow has no monarch. The princess must be crowned. I will send a message to her at once."
[Continue.]
"His Majesty's final wish was peace between Wan and Dudow. You were there."
[Continue.]

"That was his wish," the Minister of Peace conceded. "And we will obey his command and continue on our way. If the new queen wishes us to turn back, she can send word to us at Enzibar, our last stop before crossing the border. When I send her the awful news, I'll ask her to advise us."
[Continue.]

The ambassador considered this a few moments with furrowed brow. The reasonableness of the minister's plan stymied him.

He nodded, offering no objections.
<FirstName> decided <his/her> presence was now rather inappropriate and excused <him/her>self.

"Yes, go on. Just -- please! Keep this to yourself. "If you'll excuse me, Minister, young witch -- I must prepare letters of apology to Wan. I do hope I won't need to send them. Minister, please impress on our visitor the importance of keeping this secret. What would Zidae say if she heard the news of her father's death from a witch instead of you?"
[Continue.]
"Is there anything I can do?"
"You?" asked the minister, surprised. He seemed to have forgotten about <him/her> once again.
[Continue.]

"No, I don't think so," said the ambassador. "Just -- please! Keep this to yourself." "If you'll excuse me, Minister, young witch -- I must prepare letters of apology to Wan. I do hope I won't need to send them. Minister, please impress on our visitor the importance of keeping this secret. What would Zidae say if she heard the news of her father's death from a witch instead of you?"
[Continue.]
This grim fancy persuaded the Minister of Peace to lecture <FirstName> on the importance of secrecy for several minutes. When he had finally finished, he hurried off to write the princess.
[End.]
"Did someone murder him?"
"Murder! No!"
[Continue.]
"Absolutely not -- you can be sure of that."
[Continue.]
Though the ambassador and the Minister of Peace clearly had their differences, they united to reject this possibility.
[Continue.]
"His Majesty was in bad health. I think he knew this journey would be his last. He never would have left the castle if he didn't believe it was vital to his legacy."
"I don't care enough to tell anyone, but I'll do it out of spite if you don't watch yourself."
Astimund couldn't think of anything to say to this. He stopped insisting.
"How did this happen?"
"Why are you trying to keep this secret?"
"Did someone murder him?"
"I swear."
"I hope you're true to your word."
"How did this happen?"
"Why are you trying to keep this secret?"
"Did someone murder him?"
